Introduction

Strabismus is ocular misalignment in any direction (eg, horizontal, vertical), occurring in about 4% of the population.  If untreated in childhood, strabismus can lead to amblyopia (ie, functional reduction in visual acuity due to abnormal development of the visual cortex) in the misaligned eye.

Pathophysiology and risk factors

Six extraocular muscles control movement of each eye.  Strabismus occurs when there is an imbalance or uncoordinated control of movement, causing eye deviation.  Many cases are idiopathic, but known causes include:

  • Congenital causes (eg, congenital fourth nerve palsy)
  • Acquired causes:
    • Structural abnormalities of the eye or orbit (eg, orbital fracture entrapping the inferior rectus muscle)
    • Refractive errors (eg, hyperopia causing excess convergence when focusing on near objects)
    • Neuromuscular disorders affecting control of eye movements (eg, myasthenia gravis, multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy)
    • Central nervous system disorders (eg, tumors, infections)
    • Endocrine disorders (eg, TSH receptor autoantibodies cause inflammation within the extraocular muscles and connective tissue)

In addition to the causes above, other factors that increase the risk for strabismus include prematurity and family history of strabismus.

Clinical presentation

The clinical presentation of strabismus can vary, depending on the type and severity of the condition.  Eye deviation can occur in any direction but is most common in the nasal (esotropia) or temporal (exotropia) direction.  Strabismus may be present at all times or latent (ie, present only when binocular vision is disrupted).

Presenting signs and symptoms may include:

  • Visible misalignment of the eyes, which may be more pronounced when the patient is focusing on nearby objects or looking in a certain direction
  • Torticollis or head tilt to compensate for the misalignment
  • Closing one eye to focus
  • Impaired depth perception
  • Diplopia

Diagnostic evaluation

Strabismus is often detected during routine eye examination (eg, visual acuity testing, pupillary reactivity).  Tests that screen specifically for strabismus include:

  • Red reflex and corneal light reflection (
    figure 1
    ):  While the patient is looking at a fixed target, the examiner holds a penlight next to the target, shining it at the patient's eyes.  The results are normal if the light reflex is positioned symmetrically and centrally in each eye.  With a direct ophthalmoscope, the red reflexes from both eyes can also be compared.  The results are normal if both reflexes are identical in shape, size, color, and brightness.
  • Cover test:  While the patient is looking at a fixed target, the examiner covers one of the patient's eyes and observes the opposite eye for movement.  The results are normal if there is no movement.  Movement indicates that the misaligned eye shifts to fixate on the target when the normal eye is covered.
  • Cover/uncover test:  While the patient is looking at a fixed target, the examiner covers one of the patient's eyes for a few seconds, then rapidly uncovers it.  The eye that was covered is observed for movement.  The results are normal if there is no movement.  Movement indicates that the eye deviates away while covered and shifts to refixate on the target.

Although most cases of strabismus are idiopathic or related to accommodative errors, the underlying cause can be life-threatening.  In fact, esotropia is the second most common presentation of retinoblastoma (an intraocular malignancy) after leukocoria (

figure 2
).  Therefore, if strabismus is suspected, a dilated funduscopic examination should be performed to assess for secondary causes; retinoblastoma can often be visualized as a nodular, off-white retinal mass (
image 1
).

Laboratory evaluation is generally not required for the diagnosis of strabismus.  However, imaging studies may be obtained if underlying neurologic or structural abnormalities are suspected.

Differential diagnosis

The differential diagnosis for strabismus includes:

  • Pseudoesotropia:  A false appearance of strabismus may occur in children with a wide nasal bridge and/or large epicanthal folds (
    image 2
    ), in which the nasal side of the sclera is covered, making the eye appear to be esotropic.  However, symmetric corneal light reflexes and a normal cover and cover/uncover test distinguish pseudoesotropia from strabismus.
  • Ocular instability of infancy:  Newborns may have unsteady ocular alignment in the first few months of life.  This is characterized by intermittent deviation of the eyes (
    image 3
    ) and typically resolves by age 6 months.

Management

Intermittent strabismus that occurs beyond early infancy (ie, age >4-6 months) or constant eye deviation at any age must be treated to prevent amblyopia (

), a functional reduction in visual acuity that occurs due to disuse of the deviated eye.

The goal of management is to improve ocular alignment and binocular vision.  Treatment depends on the etiology but may include:

  • Correction of significant refractive errors to promote use of the affected eye.
  • Application of a patch (
    figure 3
    ) or cycloplegic drops (eg, atropine) to blur vision of the normal eye and to promote use of the affected eye.  Young children with strabismus typically ignore the visual stimulus coming from the misaligned eye, which leads to amblyopia.  Patching the normal eye forces the visual cortex to recognize the signal coming from the misaligned eye.  As a result, the nerve pathways from the misaligned eye are stimulated to develop.
  • Vision therapy (eg, exercises using prisms, filters) to improve binocular vision and eye coordination.
  • Surgical procedures to improve ocular alignment.

Prognosis

The prognosis for strabismus depends on various factors, including the age of onset, severity of misalignment, and underlying cause.  Complications of untreated strabismus include:

  • Amblyopia:  Because of the abnormal binocular interactions, young children with strabismus typically suppress the signal coming from the misaligned eye.  Persistently impaired transmission of visual stimuli causes abnormal development of the visual cortex.  As a result, there is reduced functional visual acuity in the misaligned eye (ie, amblyopia).
  • Diplopia (ie, double vision):  In older children or adults who develop strabismus later in life, they are typically unable to suppress the 2 visual signals coming from ocular misalignment.  As a result, patients experience double vision.
  • Adverse psychosocial consequences:  Due to the appearance and function of the eyes, patients may have difficulty with self-image and experience depression.

With early detection and intervention, many patients achieve improved ocular alignment and visual function following appropriate management.

Summary

Strabismus (
